*.description: A local cache

start.description: The cache start mode, which can be EAGER (immediate start) or LAZY (on-demand start).

batching.description: If enabled, the invocation batching API will be made available for this cache.

indexing.description: If enabled, entries will be indexed when they are added to the cache. Indexes will be updated as entries change or are removed.

jndi-name.description: The jndi-name to which to bind this cache instance.

locking.description: The locking configuration of the cache.

LOCKING.description: The locking configuration of the cache.

isolation.description: Sets the cache locking isolation level.

striping.description: If true, a pool of shared locks is maintained for all entries that need to be locked. Otherwise, a lock is created per entry in the cache. Lock striping helps control memory footprint but may reduce concurrency in the system.

acquire-timeout.description: Maximum time to attempt a particular lock acquisition.

concurrency-level.description: Concurrency level for lock containers. Adjust this value according to the number of concurrent threads interacting with Infinispan.

mode.description: Sets the cache transaction mode to one of NONE, NON_XA, NON_DURABLE_XA, FULL_XA.

stop-timeout.description: If there are any ongoing transactions when a cache is stopped, Infinispan waits for ongoing remote and local transactions to finish. The amount of time to wait for is defined by the cache stop timeout.

locking.description: The locking mode for this cache, one of OPTIMISTIC or PESSIMISTIC.

strategy.description: Sets the cache eviction strategy. Available options are 'UNORDERED', 'FIFO', 'LRU', 'LIRS' and 'NONE' (to disable eviction).

max-entries.description: Maximum number of entries in a cache instance. If selected value is not a power of two the actual value will default to the least power of two larger than selected value. -1 means no limit.

max-idle.description: Maximum idle time a cache entry will be maintained in the cache, in milliseconds. If the idle time is exceeded, the entry will be expired cluster-wide. -1 means the entries never expire.

lifespan.description: Maximum lifespan of a cache entry, after which the entry is expired cluster-wide, in milliseconds. -1 means the entries never expire.

interval.description: Interval (in milliseconds) between subsequent runs to purge expired entries from memory and any cache stores. If you wish to disable the periodic eviction process altogether, set wakeupInterval to -1.

shared.description: This setting should be set to true when multiple cache instances share the same cache store (e.g., multiple nodes in a cluster using a JDBC-based CacheStore pointing to the same, shared database.) Setting this to true avoids multiple cache instances writing the same modification multiple times. If enabled, only the node where the modification originated will write to the cache store. If disabled, each individual cache reacts to a potential remote update by storing the data to the cache store.

preload.description: If true, when the cache starts, data stored in the cache store will be pre-loaded into memory. This is particularly useful when data in the cache store will be needed immediately after startup and you want to avoid cache operations being delayed as a result of loading this data lazily. Can be used to provide a 'warm-cache' on startup, however there is a performance penalty as startup time is affected by this process.

passivation.description: If true, data is only written to the cache store when it is evicted from memory, a phenomenon known as 'passivation'. Next time the data is requested, it will be 'activated' which means that data will be brought back to memory and removed from the persistent store. f false, the cache store contains a copy of the contents in memory, so writes to cache result in cache store writes. This essentially gives you a 'write-through' configuration.

fetch-state.description: If true, fetch persistent state when joining a cluster. If multiple cache stores are chained, only one of them can have this property enabled.

purge.description: If true, purges this cache store when it starts up.

singleton.description: If true, the singleton store cache store is enabled. SingletonStore is a delegating cache store used for situations when only one instance in a cluster should interact with the underlying store.

class.description: The custom store implementation class to use for this cache store.

write-behind.description: Configures a cache store as write-behind instead of write-through.

WRITE_BEHIND.description: Configures a cache store as write-behind instead of write-through.

flush-lock-timeout.description: Timeout to acquire the lock which guards the state to be flushed to the cache store periodically.

modification-queue-size.description: Maximum number of entries in the asynchronous queue. When the queue is full, the store becomes write-through until it can accept new entries.

thread-pool-size.description: Size of the thread pool whose threads are responsible for applying the modifications to the cache store.

shutdown-timeout.description: Timeout in milliseconds to stop the cache store.

property.description: A cache store property with name and value.

shared.description: This setting should be set to true when multiple cache instances share the same cache store (e.g., multiple nodes in a cluster using a JDBC-based CacheStore pointing to the same, shared database.) Setting this to true avoids multiple cache instances writing the same modification multiple times. If enabled, only the node where the modification originated will write to the cache store. If disabled, each individual cache reacts to a potential remote update by storing the data to the cache store.

preload.description: If true, when the cache starts, data stored in the cache store will be pre-loaded into memory. This is particularly useful when data in the cache store will be needed immediately after startup and you want to avoid cache operations being delayed as a result of loading this data lazily. Can be used to provide a 'warm-cache' on startup, however there is a performance penalty as startup time is affected by this process.

passivation.description: If true, data is only written to the cache store when it is evicted from memory, a phenomenon known as 'passivation'. Next time the data is requested, it will be 'activated' which means that data will be brought back to memory and removed from the persistent store. f false, the cache store contains a copy of the contents in memory, so writes to cache result in cache store writes. This essentially gives you a 'write-through' configuration.

start.description: The cache start mode, which can be EAGER (immediate start) or LAZY (on-demand start).

batching.description: If enabled, the invocation batching API will be made available for this cache.

indexing.description: If enabled, entries will be indexed when they are added to the cache. Indexes will be updated as entries change or are removed.

jndi-name.description: The jndi-name to which to bind this cache instance.

async-marshalling.description: If enabled, this will cause marshalling of entries to be performed asynchronously.

mode.description: Sets the clustered cache mode, ASYNC for asynchronous operation, or SYNC for synchronous operation.

queue-size.description: In ASYNC mode, this attribute can be used to trigger flushing of the queue when it reaches a specific threshold.

queue-flush-interval.description: In ASYNC mode, this attribute controls how often the asynchronous thread used to flush the replication queue runs. This should be a positive integer which represents thread wakeup time in milliseconds.

remote-timeout.description: In SYNC mode, the timeout (in ms) used to wait for an acknowledgment when making a remote call, after which the call is aborted and an exception is thrown.

locking.description: The locking configuration of the cache.

LOCKING.description: The locking configuration of the cache.

isolation.description: Sets the cache locking isolation level.

striping.description: If true, a pool of shared locks is maintained for all entries that need to be locked. Otherwise, a lock is created per entry in the cache. Lock striping helps control memory footprint but may reduce concurrency in the system.

acquire-timeout.description: Maximum time to attempt a particular lock acquisition.

concurrency-level.description: Concurrency level for lock containers. Adjust this value according to the number of concurrent threads interacting with Infinispan.

mode.description: Sets the cache transaction mode to one of NONE, NON_XA, NON_DURABLE_XA, FULL_XA.

stop-timeout.description: If there are any ongoing transactions when a cache is stopped, Infinispan waits for ongoing remote and local transactions to finish. The amount of time to wait for is defined by the cache stop timeout.

locking.description: The locking mode for this cache, one of OPTIMISTIC or PESSIMISTIC.

strategy.description: Sets the cache eviction strategy. Available options are 'UNORDERED', 'FIFO', 'LRU', 'LIRS' and 'NONE' (to disable eviction).

max-entries.description: Maximum number of entries in a cache instance. If selected value is not a power of two the actual value will default to the least power of two larger than selected value. -1 means no limit.

max-idle.description: Maximum idle time a cache entry will be maintained in the cache, in milliseconds. If the idle time is exceeded, the entry will be expired cluster-wide. -1 means the entries never expire.

lifespan.description: Maximum lifespan of a cache entry, after which the entry is expired cluster-wide, in milliseconds. -1 means the entries never expire.

interval.description: Interval (in milliseconds) between subsequent runs to purge expired entries from memory and any cache stores. If you wish to disable the periodic eviction process altogether, set wakeupInterval to -1.

If disabled, each individual cache reacts to a potential remote update by storing the data to the cache store.

preload.description: If true, when the cache starts, data stored in the cache store will be pre-loaded into memory. This is particularly useful when data in the cache store will be needed immediately after startup and you want to avoid cache operations being delayed as a result of loading this data lazily. Can be used to provide a 'warm-cache' on startup, however there is a performance penalty as startup time is affected by this process.

passivation.description: If true, data is only written to the cache store when it is evicted from memory, a phenomenon known as 'passivation'. Next time the data is requested, it will be 'activated' which means that data will be brought back to memory and removed from the persistent store. f false, the cache store contains a copy of the contents in memory, so writes to cache result in cache store writes. This essentially gives you a 'write-through' configuration.

fetch-state.description: If true, fetch persistent state when joining a cluster. If multiple cache stores are chained, only one of them can have this property enabled.

purge.description: If true, purges this cache store when it starts up.

singleton.description: If true, the singleton store cache store is enabled. SingletonStore is a delegating cache store used for situations when only one instance in a cluster should interact with the underlying store.

cache.description: The name of the remote cache to use for this remote store.

tcp-no-delay.description: A TCP_NODELAY value for remote cache communication.

socket-timeout.description: A socket timeout for remote cache communication.

remote-servers.description: A list of remote servers for this cache store.

remote-server.description: A remote server, defined by its outbound socket binding.

outbound-socket-binding.description: An outbound socket binding for a remote server.

write-behind.description: Configures a cache store as write-behind instead of write-through.

WRITE_BEHIND.description: Configures a cache store as write-behind instead of write-through.

flush-lock-timeout.description: Timeout to acquire the lock which guards the state to be flushed to the cache store periodically.

modification-queue-size.description: Maximum number of entries in the asynchronous queue. When the queue is full, the store becomes write-through until it can accept new entries.

thread-pool-size.description: Size of the thread pool whose threads are responsible for applying the modifications to the cache store.

shutdown-timeout.description: Timeout in milliseconds to stop the cache store.

start.description: The cache start mode, which can be EAGER (immediate start) or LAZY (on-demand start).

batching.description: If enabled, the invocation batching API will be made available for this cache.

indexing.description: If enabled, entries will be indexed when they are added to the cache. Indexes will be updated as entries change or are removed.

jndi-name.description: The jndi-name to which to bind this cache instance.

async-marshalling.description: If enabled, this will cause marshalling of entries to be performed asynchronously.

mode.description: Sets the clustered cache mode, ASYNC for asynchronous operation, or SYNC for synchronous operation.

queue-size.description: In ASYNC mode, this attribute can be used to trigger flushing of the queue when it reaches a specific threshold.

queue-flush-interval.description: In ASYNC mode, this attribute controls how often the asynchronous thread used to flush the replication queue runs. This should be a positive integer which represents thread wakeup time in milliseconds.

remote-timeout.description: In SYNC mode, the timeout (in ms) used to wait for an acknowledgment when making a remote call, after which the call is aborted and an exception is thrown.

locking.description: The locking configuration of the cache.

LOCKING.description: The locking configuration of the cache.

isolation.description: Sets the cache locking isolation level.

striping.description: If true, a pool of shared locks is maintained for all entries that need to be locked. Otherwise, a lock is created per entry in the cache. Lock striping helps control memory footprint but may reduce concurrency in the system.

acquire-timeout.description: Maximum time to attempt a particular lock acquisition.

concurrency-level.description: Concurrency level for lock containers. Adjust this value according to the number of concurrent threads interacting with Infinispan.

mode.description: Sets the cache transaction mode to one of NONE, NON_XA, NON_DURABLE_XA, FULL_XA.

stop-timeout.description: If there are any ongoing transactions when a cache is stopped, Infinispan waits for ongoing remote and local transactions to finish. The amount of time to wait for is defined by the cache stop timeout.

locking.description: The locking mode for this cache, one of OPTIMISTIC or PESSIMISTIC.

strategy.description: Sets the cache eviction strategy. Available options are 'UNORDERED', 'FIFO', 'LRU', 'LIRS' and 'NONE' (to disable eviction).

max-entries.description: Maximum number of entries in a cache instance. If selected value is not a power of two the actual value will default to the least power of two larger than selected value. -1 means no limit.

max-idle.description: Maximum idle time a cache entry will be maintained in the cache, in milliseconds. If the idle time is exceeded, the entry will be expired cluster-wide. -1 means the entries never expire.

lifespan.description: Maximum lifespan of a cache entry, after which the entry is expired cluster-wide, in milliseconds. -1 means the entries never expire.

interval.description: Interval (in milliseconds) between subsequent runs to purge expired entries from memory and any cache stores. If you wish to disable the periodic eviction process altogether, set wakeupInterval to -1.

passivation.description: If true, data is only written to the cache store when it is evicted from memory, a phenomenon known as 'passivation'. Next time the data is requested, it will be 'activated' which means that data will be brought back to memory and removed from the persistent store. f false, the cache store contains a copy of the contents in memory, so writes to cache result in cache store writes. This essentially gives you a 'write-through' configuration.

fetch-state.description: If true, fetch persistent state when joining a cluster. If multiple cache stores are chained, only one of them can have this property enabled.

purge.description: If true, purges this cache store when it starts up.

singleton.description: If true, the singleton store cache store is enabled. SingletonStore is a delegating cache store used for situations when only one instance in a cluster should interact with the underlying store.

write-behind.description: Configures a cache store as write-behind instead of write-through.

WRITE_BEHIND.description: Configures a cache store as write-behind instead of write-through.

flush-lock-timeout.description: Timeout to acquire the lock which guards the state to be flushed to the cache store periodically.

modification-queue-size.description: Maximum number of entries in the asynchronous queue. When the queue is full, the store becomes write-through until it can accept new entries.

thread-pool-size.description: Size of the thread pool whose threads are responsible for applying the modifications to the cache store.

shutdown-timeout.description: Timeout in milliseconds to stop the cache store.

shared.description: This setting should be set to true when multiple cache instances share the same cache store (e.g., multiple nodes in a cluster using a JDBC-based CacheStore pointing to the same, shared database.) Setting this to true avoids multiple cache instances writing the same modification multiple times. If enabled, only the node where the modification originated will write to the cache store. If disabled, each individual cache reacts to a potential remote update by storing the data to the cache store.

ejb3.description: The configuration of the ejb3 subsystem.

default-mdb-instance-pool.description: Name of the default MDB instance pool, which will be applicable to all MDBs, unless overridden at the deployment or bean level

default-entity-bean-optimistic-locking.description: If set to true entity beans will use optimistic locking by default

in-vm-remote-interface-invocation-pass-b.description: If set to false, the parameters to invocations on remote interface of an EJB, will be passed by reference. Else, the parameters will be passed by value.

default-clustered-sfsb-cache.description: Name of the default stateful bean cache, which will be applicable to all clustered stateful EJBs, unless overridden at the deployment or bean level

default-entity-bean-instance-pool.description: Name of the default entity bean instance pool, which will be applicable to all entity beans, unless overridden at the deployment or bean level

default-singleton-bean-access-timeout.description: The default access timeout for singleton beans

default-sfsb-cache.description: Name of the default stateful bean cache, which will be applicable to all stateful EJBs, unless overridden at the deployment or bean level

default-resource-adapter-name.description: Name of the default resource adapter name that will be used by MDBs, unless overridden at the deployment or bean level

default-stateful-bean-access-timeout.description: The default access timeout for stateful beans

default-slsb-instance-pool.description: Name of the default stateless bean instance pool, which will be applicable to all stateless EJBs, unless overridden at the deployment or bean level

service.description: Centrally configurable services that are part of the EJB3 subsystem.

thread-pool-name.description: The name of the thread pool which handles asynchronous invocations

enable-by-default.description: If this is true EJB's will be exposed over IIOP by default, otherwise it needs to be explicitly enabled in the deployment descriptor

use-qualified-name.description: If true EJB names will be bound into the naming service with the application and module name prepended to the name (e.g. myapp/mymodule/MyEjb)

thread-pool-name.description: The name of the thread pool that handles remote invocations

connector-ref.description: The name of the connector on which the EJB3 remoting channel is registered

path.description: The directory to store persistent timer information in

thread-pool-name.description: The name of the thread pool used to run timer service invocations

relative-to.description: The relative path that is used to resolve the timer data store location

*.description: A thread pool executor with an unbounded queue.  Such a thread pool has a core size and a queue with no upper bound.  When a task is submitted, if the number of running threads is less than the core size, a new thread is created.  Otherwise, the task is placed in queue.  If too many tasks are allowed to be submitted to this type of executor, an out of memory condition may occur.

active-count.description: The approximate number of threads that are actively executing tasks.

current-thread-count.description: The current number of threads in the pool.

task-count.description: The approximate total number of tasks that have ever been scheduled for execution.

largest-thread-count.description: The largest number of threads that have ever simultaneously been in the pool.

keepalive-time.description: Used to specify the amount of time that pool threads should be kept running when idle; if not specified, threads will run until the executor is shut down.

thread-factory.description: Specifies the name of a specific thread factory to use to create worker threads. If not defined an appropriate default thread factory will be used.

completed-task-count.description: The approximate total number of tasks that have completed execution.

name.description: The name of the thread pool.

rejected-count.description: The number of tasks that have been rejected.

file-passivation-store.description: A file system based passivation store

*.description: A file system based passivation store

idle-timeout.description: The timeout in units specified by idle-timeout-unit, after which a bean will passivate

max-size.description: The maximum number of beans this cache should store before forcing old beans to passivate

strict-max-bean-instance-pool.description: A bean instance pool with a strict upper limit

*.description: A bean instance pool with a strict upper limit

max-pool-size.description: The maximum number of bean instances that the pool can hold at a given point in time

timeout.description: The maximum amount of time to wait for a bean instance to be available from the pool

*.description: A SFSB cache

aliases.description: The aliases by which this cache may also be referenced

passivation-store.description: The passivation store used by this cache

*.description: A clustered passivation store

idle-timeout.description: The timeout in units specified by idle-timeout-unit, after which a bean will passivate

cache-container.description: The name of the cache container used for the bean and client-mappings caches

client-mappings-cache.description: The name of the cache used to store client-mappings of the EJB remoting connector's socket-bindings

bean-cache.description: The name of the cache used to store bean instances.

passivate-events-on-replicate.description: Indicates whether replication should trigger passivation events on the bean

max-size.description: The maximum number of beans this cache should store before forcing old beans to passivate

transactions.description: The configuration of the transactions subsystem.

relative-to.description: References a global path configuration in the domain model, defaulting to the JBoss Application Server data directory (jboss.server.data.dir). The value of the "path" attribute will treated as relative to this path. Use an empty string to disable the default behavior and force the value of the "path" attribute to be treated as an absolute path.

process-id-uuid.description: Indicates whether the transaction manager should use a UUID based process id.

number-of-nested-transactions.description: The total number of nested (sub) transactions created.

socket-binding.description: Used to reference the correct socket binding to use for the recovery environment.

number-of-timed-out-transactions.description: The number of transactions that have rolled back due to timeout.

jts.description: If true this enables the Java Transaction Service

number-of-transactions.description: The total number of transactions (top-level and nested) created

object-store-path.description: Denotes a relative or absolute filesystem path denoting where the transaction manager object store should store data. By default the value is treated as relative to the path denoted by the "relative-to" attribute.

path.description: Denotes a relative or absolute filesystem path denoting where the transaction manager core should store data. By default the value is treated as relative to the path denoted by the "relative-to" attribute.

number-of-heuristics.description: The number of transactions which have terminated with heuristic outcomes.

process-id-socket-binding.description: The name of the socket binding configuration to use if the transaction manager should use a socket-based process id. Will be 'undefined' if 'process-id-uuid' is 'true'; otherwise must be set.

number-of-aborted-transactions.description: The number of aborted (i.e. rolledback) transactions.

process-id-socket-max-ports.description: The maximum number of ports to search for an open port if the transaction manager should use a socket-based process id. If the port specified by the socket binding referenced in 'process-id-socket-binding' is occupied, the next higher port will be tried until an open port is found or the number of ports specified by this attribute have been tried. Will be 'undefined' if 'process-id-uuid' is 'true'.

number-of-inflight-transactions.description: The number of transactions that have begun but not yet terminated.

recovery-listener.description: Used to specify if the recovery system should listen on a network socket or not.

number-of-application-rollbacks.description: The number of transactions that have been rolled back by application request. This includes those that timeout, since the timeout behaviour is considered an attribute of the application configuration.

status-socket-binding.description: Used to reference the correct socket binding to use for the transaction status manager.

node-identifier.description: Used to set the node identifier on the core environment.

enable-tsm-status.description: Whether the transaction status manager (TSM) service, needed for out of process recovery, should be provided or not..

object-store-relative-to.description: References a global path configuration in the domain model, defaulting to the JBoss Application Server data directory (jboss.server.data.dir). The value of the "path" attribute will treated as relative to this path. Use an empty string to disable the default behavior and force the value of the "path" attribute to be treated as an absolute path.

number-of-resource-rollbacks.description: The number of transactions that rolled back due to resource (participant) failure.

datasources.description: The data-sources subsystem, used to declare JDBC data-sources

installed-drivers.description: List of JDBC drivers that have been installed in the runtime

deployment-name.description: The name of the deployment unit from which the driver was loaded

driver-name.description: The symbolic name of this driver used to reference it in the registry

driver-module-name.description: The name of the module from which the driver was loaded, if it was loaded from the module path

module-slot.description: The slot of the module from which the driver was loaded, if it was loaded from the module path

driver-class-name.description: The fully qualified class name of the java.sql.Driver implementation

driver-datasource-class-name.description: The fully qualified class name of the javax.sql.DataSource implementation

driver-xa-datasource-class-name.description: The fully qualified class name of the javax.sql.XADataSource implementation

jdbc-compliant.description: Whether or not the driver is JDBC compliant

jdbc-driver.description: Service that make a JDBC driver available for use in the runtime

*.description: A service that makes a JDBC driver available for use in the runtime

driver-name.description: The symbolic name of this driver used to reference it in the registry

deployment-name.description: The name of the deployment unit from which the driver was loaded

driver-module-name.description: The name of the module from which the driver was loaded, if it was loaded from the module path

module-slot.description: The slot of the module from which the driver was loaded, if it was loaded from the module path

driver-class-name.description: The fully qualified class name of the java.sql.Driver implementation

xa-datasource-class.description: The fully qualified class name of the javax.sql.XADataSource implementation

jdbc-compliant.description: Whether or not the driver is JDBC compliant

*.description: A JDBC data-source configuration

driver-class.description: The fully qualified name of the JDBC driver class

datasource-class.description: The fully qualified name of the JDBC datasource class

jndi-name.description: Specifies the JNDI name for the datasource

driver-name.description: Defines the JDBC driver the datasource should use. It is a symbolic name matching the the name of installed driver. In case the driver is deployed as jar, the name is the name of deployment unit

new-connection-sql.description: Specifies an SQL statement to execute whenever a connection is added to the connection pool

url-delimiter.description: Specifies the delimiter for URLs in connection-url for HA datasources

use-java-context.description: Setting this to false will bind the datasource into global JNDI

max-pool-size.description: The max-pool-size element specifies the maximum number of connections for a pool. No more connections will be created in each sub-pool

min-pool-size.description: The min-pool-size element specifies the minimum number of connections for a pool

pool-prefill.description: Should the pool be prefilled. Changing this value can be done only on disabled datasource, requires a server restart otherwise.

pool-use-strict-min.description: Specifies if the min-pool-size should be considered strictly

user-name.description: Specify the user name used when creating a new connection

password.description: Specifies the password used when creating a new connection

security-domain.description: Specifies the security domain which defines the javax.security.auth.Subject that are used to distinguish connections in the pool

reauth-plugin-class-name.description: The fully qualified class name of the reauthentication plugin implementation

reauth-plugin-properties.description: The properties for the reauthentication plugin

flush-strategy.description: Specifies how the pool should be flush in case of an error. Valid values are: FailingConnectionOnly (default), IdleConnections and EntirePool

prepared-statements-cache-size.description: The number of prepared statements per connection in an LRU cache

share-prepared-statements.description: Whether to share prepared statements, i.e. whether asking for same statement twice without closing uses the same underlying prepared statement

track-statements.description: Whether to check for unclosed statements when a connection is returned to the pool, result sets are closed, a statement is closed or return to the prepared statement cache. Valid values are: "false" - do not track statements, "true" - track statements and result sets and warn when they are not closed, "nowarn" - track statements but do not warn about them being unclosed

allocation-retry.description: The allocation retry element indicates the number of times that allocating a connection should be tried before throwing an exception

allocation-retry-wait-millis.description: The allocation retry wait millis element specifies the amount of time, in milliseconds, to wait between retrying to allocate a connection

blocking-timeout-wait-millis.description: The blocking-timeout-millis element specifies the maximum time, in milliseconds, to block while waiting for a connection before throwing an exception. Note that this blocks only while waiting for locking a connection, and will never throw an exception if creating a new connection takes an inordinately long time

idle-timeout-minutes.description: The idle-timeout-minutes elements specifies the maximum time, in minutes, a connection may be idle before being closed. The actual maximum time depends also on the IdleRemover scan time, which is half of the smallest idle-timeout-minutes value of any pool. Changing this value can be done only on disabled datasource, requires a server restart otherwise.

query-timeout.description: Any configured query timeout in seconds. If not provided no timeout will be set

use-try-lock.description: Any configured timeout for internal locks on the resource adapter objects in seconds

set-tx-query-timeout.description: Whether to set the query timeout based on the time remaining until transaction timeout. Any configured query timeout will be used if there is no transaction

transaction-isolation.description: Set the java.sql.Connection transaction isolation level. Valid values are: TRANSACTION_READ_UNCOMMITTED, TRANSACTION_READ_COMMITTED, TRANSACTION_REPEATABLE_READ, TRANSACTION_SERIALIZABLE and TRANSACTION_NONE

check-valid-connection-sql.description: Specify an SQL statement to check validity of a pool connection. This may be called when managed connection is obtained from the pool

exception-sorter-class-name.description: An org.jboss.jca.adapters.jdbc.ExceptionSorter that provides an isExceptionFatal(SQLException) method to validate if an exception should broadcast an error

stale-connection-checker-class-name.description: An org.jboss.jca.adapters.jdbc.StaleConnectionChecker that provides an isStaleConnection(SQLException) method which if it returns true will wrap the exception in an org.jboss.jca.adapters.jdbc.StaleConnectionException

valid-connection-checker-class-name.description: An org.jboss.jca.adapters.jdbc.ValidConnectionChecker that provides an isValidConnection(Connection) method to validate a connection. If an exception is returned that means the connection is invalid. This overrides the check-valid-connection-sql element

background-validation-millis.description: The background-validation-millis element specifies the amount of time, in milliseconds, that background validation will run. Changing this value can be done only on disabled datasource,  requires a server restart otherwise

background-validation.description: An element to specify that connections should be validated on a background thread versus being validated prior to use. Changing this value can be done only on disabled datasource,  requires a server restart otherwise.

use-fast-fail.description: Whether to fail a connection allocation on the first try if it is invalid (true) or keep trying until the pool is exhausted of all potential connections (false)

validate-on-match.description: The validate-on-match element specifies if connection validation should be done when a connection factory attempts to match a managed connection. This is typically exclusive to the use of background validation

use-ccm.description: Enable the use of a cached connection manager

enabled.description: Specifies if the datasource should be enabled

connection-properties.description: The connection-properties element allows you to pass in arbitrary connection properties to the Driver.connect(url, props) method

*.description: value

value.description: Each connection-property specifies a string name/value pair with the property name coming from the name attribute and the value coming from the element content

*.description: A JDBC XA data-source configuration

xa-datasource-class.description: The fully qualified name of the javax.sql.XADataSource implementation

jndi-name.description: Specifies the JNDI name for the datasource

driver-name.description: Defines the JDBC driver the datasource should use. It is a symbolic name matching the the name of installed driver. In case the driver is deployed as jar, the name is the name of deployment unit

new-connection-sql.description: Specifies an SQL statement to execute whenever a connection is added to the connection pool

url-delimiter.description: Specifies the delimiter for URLs in connection-url for HA datasources

use-java-context.description: Setting this to false will bind the datasource into global JNDI

max-pool-size.description: The max-pool-size element specifies the maximum number of connections for a pool. No more connections will be created in each sub-pool

min-pool-size.description: The min-pool-size element specifies the minimum number of connections for a pool

pool-prefill.description: Should the pool be prefilled. Changing this value can be done only on disabled datasource, requires a server restart otherwise.

pool-use-strict-min.description: Specifies if the min-pool-size should be considered strictly

interleaving.description: An element to enable interleaving for XA connections

no-tx-separate-pool.description: Oracle does not like XA connections getting used both inside and outside a JTA transaction. To workaround the problem you can create separate sub-pools for the different contexts

same-rm-override.description: The is-same-rm-override element allows one to unconditionally set whether the javax.transaction.xa.XAResource.isSameRM(XAResource) returns true or false

wrap-xa-resource.description: Should the XAResource instances be wrapped in a org.jboss.tm.XAResourceWrapper instance

user-name.description: Specify the user name used when creating a new connection

password.description: Specifies the password used when creating a new connection

security-domain.description: Specifies the security domain which defines the javax.security.auth.Subject that are used to distinguish connections in the pool

reauth-plugin-class-name.description: The fully qualified class name of the reauthentication plugin implementation

reauth-plugin-properties.description: The properties for the reauthentication plugin

flush-strategy.description: Specifies how the pool should be flush in case of an error. Valid values are: FailingConnectionOnly (default), IdleConnections and EntirePool

prepared-statements-cache-size.description: The number of prepared statements per connection in an LRU cache

share-prepared-statements.description: Whether to share prepared statements, i.e. whether asking for same statement twice without closing uses the same underlying prepared statement

track-statements.description: Whether to check for unclosed statements when a connection is returned to the pool, result sets are closed, a statement is closed or return to the prepared statement cache. Valid values are: "false" - do not track statements, "true" - track statements and result sets and warn when they are not closed, "nowarn" - track statements but do not warn about them being unclosed

allocation-retry.description: The allocation retry element indicates the number of times that allocating a connection should be tried before throwing an exception

allocation-retry-wait-millis.description: The allocation retry wait millis element specifies the amount of time, in milliseconds, to wait between retrying to allocate a connection

blocking-timeout-wait-millis.description: The blocking-timeout-millis element specifies the maximum time, in milliseconds, to block while waiting for a connection before throwing an exception. Note that this blocks only while waiting for locking a connection, and will never throw an exception if creating a new connection takes an inordinately long time

idle-timeout-minutes.description: The idle-timeout-minutes elements specifies the maximum time, in minutes, a connection may be idle before being closed. The actual maximum time depends also on the IdleRemover scan time, which is half of the smallest idle-timeout-minutes value of any pool. Changing this value can be done only on disabled datasource, requires a server restart otherwise.

query-timeout.description: Any configured query timeout in seconds. If not provided no timeout will be set

use-try-lock.description: Any configured timeout for internal locks on the resource adapter objects in seconds

set-tx-query-timeout.description: Whether to set the query timeout based on the time remaining until transaction timeout. Any configured query timeout will be used if there is no transaction

transaction-isolation.description: Set the java.sql.Connection transaction isolation level. Valid values are: TRANSACTION_READ_UNCOMMITTED, TRANSACTION_READ_COMMITTED, TRANSACTION_REPEATABLE_READ, TRANSACTION_SERIALIZABLE and TRANSACTION_NONE

check-valid-connection-sql.description: Specify an SQL statement to check validity of a pool connection. This may be called when managed connection is obtained from the pool

exception-sorter-class-name.description: An org.jboss.jca.adapters.jdbc.ExceptionSorter that provides an isExceptionFatal(SQLException) method to validate if an exception should broadcast an error

stale-connection-checker-class-name.description: An org.jboss.jca.adapters.jdbc.StaleConnectionChecker that provides an isStaleConnection(SQLException) method which if it returns true will wrap the exception in an org.jboss.jca.adapters.jdbc.StaleConnectionException

valid-connection-checker-class-name.description: An org.jboss.jca.adapters.jdbc.ValidConnectionChecker that provides an isValidConnection(Connection) method to validate a connection. If an exception is returned that means the connection is invalid. This overrides the check-valid-connection-sql element

background-validation-millis.description: The background-validation-millis element specifies the amount of time, in milliseconds, that background validation will run. Changing this value can be done only on disabled datasource,  requires a server restart otherwise

background-validation.description: An element to specify that connections should be validated on a background thread versus being validated prior to use. Changing this value can be done only on disabled datasource,  requires a server restart otherwise.

use-fast-fail.description: Whether to fail a connection allocation on the first try if it is invalid (true) or keep trying until the pool is exhausted of all potential connections (false)

validate-on-match.description: The validate-on-match element specifies if connection validation should be done when a connection factory attempts to match a managed connection. This is typically exclusive to the use of background validation

xa-resource-timeout.description: The value is passed to XAResource.setTransactionTimeout(), in seconds. Default is zero

use-ccm.description: Enable the use of a cached connection manager

recovery-username.description: The user name used for recovery

recovery-security-domain.description: The security domain used for recovery

recovery-plugin-class-name.description: The fully qualified class name of the recovery plugin implementation

recovery-plugin-properties.description: The properties for the recovery plugin

no-recovery.description: Specifies if the connection pool should be excluded from recovery

enabled.description: Specifies if the datasource should be enabled

*.description: value

value.description: Specifies a property value to assign to the XADataSource implementation class. Each property is identified by the name attribute and the property value is given by the xa-datasource-property element content. The property is mapped onto the XADataSource implementation by looking for a JavaBeans style getter method for the property name. If found, the value of the property is set using the JavaBeans setter with the element text translated to the true property type using the java.beans.PropertyEditor

logging.description: The configuration of the logging subsystem.

root-logger.description: Defines the root logger for this log context.

ROOT.description: Defines the root logger for this log context.

level.description: The log level specifying which message levels will be logged by this. Message levels lower than this value will be discarded.

all.description: A filter consisting of several filters in a chain.  If any filter finds the log message to be unloggable,the message will not be logged and subsequent filters will not be checked.

change-level.description: A filter which modifies the log record with a new level if the nested filter evaluates true for that record.

level.description: A filter which excludes a message with the specified level.

level-range.description: A filter which logs only messages that fall within a level range.

max-inclusive.description: True if the max-level value is inclusive, false if it is exclusive.

relative-to.description:
The name of another previously named path, or of one of the standard paths provided by the system. If 'relative-to' is provided, the value of the 'path' attribute is treated as relative to the path specified by this attribute. The standard paths provided by the system include:
  • jboss.home - the root directory of the JBoss AS distribution
  • user.home - user's home directory
  • user.dir - user's current working directory
  • java.home - java installation directory
  • jboss.server.base.dir - root directory for an individual server instance
  • jboss.server.data.dir - directory the server will use for persistent data file storage
  • jboss.server.log.dir - directory the server will use for log file storage
  • jboss.server.tmp.dir - directory the server will use for temporary file storage
  • jboss.domain.servers.dir - directory under which a host controller will create the working area for individual server instances

class.description: The logging handler class to be used.

module.description: The module that the logging handler depends on.

properties.description: Defines the properties used for the logging handler. All properties must be accessible via a setter method.

name.description: Defines the name of the property to set.

value.description: Defines value of the property.

deployment-scanner.description: An individual deployment scanner that scans a particular location

scanner.description: The scanners maintained by the subsystem.

*.description: The configuration of the deployment scanner subsystem

relative-to.description: Reference to a filesystem path defined in the "paths" section of the server configuration.

path.description: The actual filesystem path to be scanned. Treated as an absolute path, unless the 'relative-to' attribute is specified, in which case the value is treated as relative to that path.

auto-deploy-exploded.description: Controls whether zipped deployment content should be automatically deployed by the scanner without requiring the user to add a .dodeploy marker file. Setting this to 'true' is not recommended for anything but basic development scenarios,  as there is no way to ensure that deployment will not occur in the middle of changes to the content.

auto-deploy-xml.description: Controls whether XML deployment content should be automatically deployed by the scanner without requiring the user to add a .dodeploy marker file.

scan-enabled.description: Flag indicating that all scanning (including initial scanning at startup) should be disabled.

scan-interval.description: Periodic interval, in milliseconds, at which the repository should be scanned for changes. A value of less than 1 indicates the repository should only be scanned at initial startup.

auto-deploy-zipped.description: Controls whether zipped deployment content should be automatically deployed by the scanner without requiring the user to add a .dodeploy marker file.

deployment-timeout.description: Timeout, in seconds, a deployment is allows to execute before being canceled.  The default is 60 seconds.

jpa.description: The configuration of the JPA subsystem.

default-datasource.description: The name of the default global datasource.

pojo.description: Support JBoss5 and JBoss6 pojo configuration model.

naming.description: The configuration of the naming subsystem.

*.description: JNDI bindings for primitive types

module.description: The module to load the object factory from for object factory bindings

binding-type.description: The type of binding to create, may be simple, lookup or object-factory

value.description: The value to bind for simple bindings

class.description: The object factory class name for object factory bindings

type.description: The type of the value to bind for simple bindings, this must be a primitive type

lookup.description: The entry to lookup in JNDI for lookup bindings

ee.description: The configuration of the EE subsystem.

global-modules.description: A list of modules that should be made available to all deployments.

name.description: The name of the module

ear-subdeployments-isolated.description: Flag indicating whether each of the subdeployments within a .ear can access classes belonging to another subdeployment within the same .ear. A value of false means the subdeployments can see classes belonging to other subdeployments within the .ear.

*.description: Mail session definition

jndi-name.description: JNDI name to where mail session should be bound

from.description: From address that is used as default from, if not set when sending

outbound-socket-binding-ref.description: Outbound Socket binding to POP3 server
Outbound Socket binding to POP3 server
Outbound Socket binding to POP3 server

web.description: The configuration of the jboss.web subsystem.

default-virtual-server.description: The web container's default virtual server.

instance-id.description: Set the identifier for this server instance.

native.description: Add the native initialization listener to the web container.

sendfile.description: Enable sendfile if possible, for files bigger than the specified byte size.

trim-spaces.description: Trim some spaces from the generated Servlet.

development.description: Enable the development mode, which gives more information when an error occurs.

recompile-on-fail.description: Retry failed JSP compilations on each request.

check-interval.description: Check interval for JSP updates using a background thread.

modification-test-interval.description: Minimum amount of time between two tests for updates, in seconds.

display-source-fragment.description: When a runtime error occurs, attempts to display corresponding JSP source fragment.

error-on-use-bean-invalid-class-attribut.description: Enable errors when using a bad class in useBean.

java-encoding.description: Specify the encoding used for Java sources.

generate-strings-as-char-arrays.description: Generate String constants as char arrays.

x-powered-by.description: Enable advertising the JSP engine in x-powered-by.

dump-smap.description: Write SMAP data to a file.

*.description: A virtual host.

enable-welcome-root.description: Whether or not the bundled welcome directory is used as the root web context.

default-web-module.description: The web module deployment name that will be mapped as the root webapp.

name.description: A unique virtual host name

rewrite.description: A list of rewrite rules that will be processed in order on the URL or vhost specified in the request.

*.description: A list of rewrite rules that will be processed in order on the URL or vhost specified in the request.

substitution.description: The string that will replace the original URL or vhost.

flags.description: Option flags for this rewrite rule.

pattern.description: The pattern that will be matched.

condition.description: A list of conditions this rule needs to match for rewrite to occur.

*.description: A list of conditions this rule needs to match for rewrite to occur.

sso.description: The SSO configuration for this virtual server.

configuration.description: The SSO configuration for this virtual server.

domain.description: The cookie domain that will be used.

cache-container.description: Enables clustered SSO using the specified clustered cache container.

reauthenticate.description: Enables reauthentication with the realm when using SSO.

cache-name.description: Name of the cache to use in the cache container.

access-log.description: The access log configuration for this virtual server.

configuration.description: The access log configuration for this virtual server.

rotate.description: Rotate the access log every day.

prefix.description: Prefix for the log file name.

extended.description: Enable extended pattern, with more options.

directory.description: The location for the access logging.

configuration.description: The location for the access logging.

relative-to.description: The folder the path is relative to.

bytesSent.description: Number of byte sent by the connector.

proxy-port.description: The port that will be used when sending a redirect.

secure.description: Indicates if content sent or received by the connector is secured from the user perspective.

virtual-server.description: The list of virtual servers that can be accessed through this connector. The default is to allow all virtual servers.

errorCount.description: Number of error that occurs when processing requests by the connector.

maxTime.description: Max time spent to process a requests.

socket-binding.description: The web connector socket-binding reference, this connector should be bound to.

name.description: A unique name for the connector.

max-post-size.description: Maximum size in bytes of a POST request that can be parsed by the container.

requestCount.description: Number of the request processed by the connector.

proxy-name.description: The host name that will be used when sending a redirect. The default value is null.

enabled.description: Defines whether the connector should be started on startup.

enable-lookups.description: Enable DNS lookups for Servlet API.

executor.description: The name of the executor that should be used for the processing threads of this connector. If undefined defaults to using an internal pool.

processingTime.description: Processing time used by the connector. Im milli-seconds.

redirect-port.description: The port for redirection to a secure connector.

bytesReceived.description: Number of byte received by the connector (POST data).

max-connections.description: Amount of concurrent connections that can be processed by the connector with optimum performance. The default value depends on the connector used.

max-save-post-size.description: Maximum size in bytes of a POST request that will be saved during certain authentication schemes.

ssl.description: The SSL configuration of the connector.

configuration.description: The SSL configuration of the connector.

protocol.description: The SSL protocols that are enabled.

truststore-type.description: Type of the truststore, There are various types of keystores available, including "PKCS12" and Sun's "JKS."

name.description: The configuration name.

keystore-type.description: Type of the keystore, There are various types of keystores available, including "PKCS12" and Sun's "JKS."

resource-adapters.description: Configuration of the resource adapters subsystem

resource-adapter.description: The configuration of a resource adapter

*.description: resource-adapter

transaction-support.description: Specifies the transaction support level of the resource adapter

bootstrap-context.description: Specifies the unique name of the bootstrap context that should be used

beanvalidationgroups.description: Specifies the bean validation groups that should be used

*.description: connection-definitions

class-name.description: Specifies the fully qualified class name of a managed connection factory or admin object

jndi-name.description: Specifies the JNDI name for the connection factory or admin object

use-java-context.description: Setting this to false will bind the object into global JNDI

enabled.description: Specifies if the resource adapter should be enabled

max-pool-size.description: The max-pool-size element specifies the maximum number of connections for a pool. No more connections will be created in each sub-pool

min-pool-size.description: The min-pool-size element specifies the minimum number of connections for a pool

pool-use-strict-min.description: Specifies if the min-pool-size should be considered strictly

flush-strategy.description: Specifies how the pool should be flush in case of an error. Valid values are: FailingConnectionOnly (default), IdleConnections and EntirePool

security-domain-and-application.description: Indicates that either app supplied parameters (such as from getConnection(user, pw)) or Subject (from security domain) are used to distinguish connections in the pool

security-application.description: Indicates that app supplied parameters (such as from getConnection(user, pw)) are used to distinguish connections in the pool

security-domain.description: Specifies the security domain which defines the javax.security.auth.Subject that are used to distinguish connections in the pool

allocation-retry.description: The allocation retry element indicates the number of times that allocating a connection should be tried before throwing an exception

allocation-retry-wait-millis.description: The allocation retry wait millis element specifies the amount of time, in milliseconds, to wait between retrying to allocate a connection

blocking-timeout-wait-millis.description: The blocking-timeout-millis element specifies the maximum time, in milliseconds, to block while waiting for a connection before throwing an exception. Note that this blocks only while waiting for locking a connection, and will never throw an exception if creating a new connection takes an inordinately long time

idle-timeout-minutes.description: The idle-timeout-minutes elements specifies the maximum time, in minutes, a connection may be idle before being closed. The actual maximum time depends also on the IdleRemover scan time, which is half of the smallest idle-timeout-minutes value of any pool. Changing this value requires a server restart.

xa-resource-timeout.description: The value is passed to XAResource.setTransactionTimeout(), in seconds. Default is zero

use-try-lock.description: Any configured timeout for internal locks on the resource adapter objects in seconds

background-validation-millis.description: The background-validation-millis element specifies the amount of time, in milliseconds, that background validation will run. Changing this value requires a server restart

background-validation.description: An element to specify that connections should be validated on a background thread versus being validated prior to use. Changing this value requires a server restart

use-fast-fail.description: Whether to fail a connection allocation on the first try if it is invalid (true) or keep trying until the pool is exhausted of all potential connections (false)

use-ccm.description: Enable the use of a cached connection manager

recovery-plugin-class-name.description: The fully qualified class name of the recovery plugin implementation

recovery-plugin-properties.description: The properties for the recovery plugin

recovery-security-domain.description: The security domain used for recovery

recovery-username.description: The user name used for recovery

no-recovery.description: Specifies if the connection pool should be excluded from recovery

wrap-xa-resource.description: Should the XAResource instances be wrapped in a org.jboss.tm.XAResourceWrapper instance

same-rm-override.description: The is-same-rm-override element allows one to unconditionally set whether the javax.transaction.xa.XAResource.isSameRM(XAResource) returns true or false

pool-prefill.description: Should the pool be prefilled. Changing this value requires a server restart

interleaving.description: An element to enable interleaving for XA connections

no-tx-separate-pool.description: Oracle does not like XA connections getting used both inside and outside a JTA transaction. To workaround the problem you can create separate sub-pools for the different contexts

security.description: The configuration of the security subsystem.

deep-copy-subject-mode.description: Sets the copy mode of subjects done by the security managers to be deep copies that makes copies of the subject principals and credentials if they are cloneable. It should be set to true if subject include mutable content that can be corrupted when multiple threads have the same identity and cache flushes/logout clearing the subject in one thread results in subject references affecting other threads.
